Topic.Title: Microsoft planning Xbox dashboard UI and tile changes in preparation for next-gen console (Source The Verge)....

Message.Msg: The new Xbox will be unveiled in two stages and release this holiday, a Microsoft executive has revealed. Microsoft's Aaron Greenberg said that the platform will be unveiled on May 21, while 'tons of exclusive games' will be shown at the E3 gaming expo. "We're really going to tell one story across two events," Greenberg told Major Nelson (via VideoGamer). "So we're going to start on the 21st, and really that's about revealing the next Xbox platform; our vision for the future of games, the future of entertainment. "We definitely have a lot of surprises planned. I know everyone knows the Infinity Ward team is hard at work on world premiering Call of Duty: Ghosts, so we're going to see what that looks like for the first time. "That's why we're inviting people to campus; we're going to bring them behind the scenes a little bit." Greenberg said that while the May 21 event is about laying the foundations, E3 will be focused on the software. "We've never done this before and so it's really exciting to be able to do that. It's a lot of laying the foundation, the best way to describe it. And then just a couple of weeks later we go to E3," he said. "E3 is all about the games. At E3, if you're a gamer, it's going to be tons of exclusives, world premieres, and obviously even beyond that we have a lot to share between then and this holiday." Reported features for the new Xbox include Kinect 2.0, 3D technology and the long-rumored Xbox TV.

Topic.Title: WHY Samsung Fort Knox Will NOT Work....

Message.Msg: Folks there has been much speculation why all of a sudden there is no more hype on Fort Knox as it is being tested again before it goes to the Carriers for further de-bugging.... IF you remember, back in Jan 2103, DoD awarded MSFT a near $700 million contract for Windows 8 Licenses and Office 365 software et al..... SO Goofle and Android camp made some noise so the DoD later announced that Samsung Android devices will be eligible to run on DoD's IT system and that caused a lot of celebration and fanfare by Android's fanboys.... I was skeptical as we are in the middle of a Cyberwar and how in God's name we can open a back door to the Bad guys, till I read the commentary at Apple Insider that the MAIN condition is that the staff are ONLY allowed to download Apps from the DoD's own Apps store, which basically means that the smart folks at the Pentagon have forced Samsung to close the OS by using Fort Knox. SO there goes all that phony enthusiasm as Windows 8 is already approved and we will be selling a lot of WP-8 to the USG and all the related agencies. Cheers Osso

Topic.Title: Reminder: Obama Supports Infanticide. Death Panels Next.

Message.Msg: As to facts: Obama voted in support of infanticide multiple times when he was in the Illinois Senate; that is an unambiguous fact! Obama is in bed with Planned Parenthood and funds them with taxpayer money. Just a few weeks ago a Planned Parenthood spokesperson testified to the Florida Legislature that infanticide is ok with them (they don't use the word, "infanticide" but that's what it is. As to "Death Panels" ... Obama calls them Independent Payer Advisory Boards. Their job is to "reduce payments to providers or eliminating payments for certain treatments and procedures altogether." These reduced payments will force providers to stop seeing Medicare patients, the same way an increased number of doctors have stopped taking Medicaid patients. This will lead to access problems, waiting lists and denied care for seniors. These death panels are made necessary because Obamacare added some 30 million new, mostly nonpaying, members to the health care system and needs a way to pay for them ... so he is raiding Medicare directly and through devices such as these death panels.

Message.Title: S. Carolina: Haley Leaves Health Law to U.S. as Residents Remain Uninsured
Message.Msg: Advocates for the 900,000 uninsured people in South Carolina say that thousands may not be able to enroll because the state isn’t helping implement the exchange. While the Obama administration says all exchanges will open on time Oct. 1 to cover as many as 27 million people, success in reaching them may depend on states’ willingness to help. Those states are exhibiting a continuum of cooperation. “We have seen no real attempts for the state to work with the federal government at all,” Sue Berkowitz, director of the South Carolina Appleseed Legal Justice Center, a Columbia nonprofit helping the poor, said in an interview. “Not working with the feds is, in itself, a hostile move to keep people from being able to benefit.” **************************************************** SCREW THE POOR! Message.Title: Android threats to top one million by year's end....
Message.Msg: Security firm Trend Micro has predicted the number of threats targeting the Android mobile operating system will pass the one million mark by the end of 2013. The increase would represent a near tripling of the number of threats currently known to be targeting Android. Trend Micro reported that at the end of 2012 it had detected roughly 350,000 threats targeting Google's operating system. The figure means that it has taken Android just three years to boast the same number of threats it took Windows XP 14 years to reach. "2012 was a year of real evolution in traditional threat and evolution into new platforms and geographies," said Trend Micro vice president of security research, Rik Ferguson.

Topic.Title: Android threats to top one million by year's end....

Message.Msg: "The figure means that it has taken Android just three years to boast the same number of threats it took Windows XP 14 years to reach." Um, no. The number of "threats" to XP is probably more like 8 million, according to Symantec. It's been doubling every few months for the past few years. I don't keep close track of it, there's no point. The excuse that softie shills used to give was that of course the bad guys went after XP, because it was so dominant, that's what it paid to attack. By contrast, there was little point in attacking MacOS or Linux, as so few people used it. The same argument, if it was ever valid, would apply now to Android.
